awd_titl_txt: CC* Networking Infrastructure: Cyberinfrastructure improvements for multi-disciplinary data-intensive scientific research
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses four areas of improvement in the College of William & Mary networking that expands its research capacity throughout its two campuses and aims at modernizing the data transfer capabilities. These areas are: Greater transfer speeds between main campus and the Virginia Institute of Marine Science; a Science DMZ for high-speed connectivity for research computing and a dedicated data transfer node which are monitored for quality of service with perfSONAR; addition of dedicated 10Gbps ports for offices and labs of major research network users; and the addition of a Globus license to enable efficient transfers to/from the campus research network. This work upgrades William & Mary’s research computing network to continue supporting multi-disciplinary research which demands higher transfer rates for larger data files needed to support state-of-the-art research.

These network enhancements support cross-disciplinary transformative research and discovery by investigators from W&M’s School of Marine Science (Virginia Institute of Marine Science or VIMS) and W&M’s Global Research Institute, as well as by researchers from Physics, Computer Science and Data Science. The research from this group of scientists contributes largely to the advancement and transformation of various frontiers of knowledge and discovery. Projects like 3D Environmental Flow Modeling, Lattice Quantum Chromodynamics (LQCD, Coastal Biogeochemical Modeling, Deep Learning for Estimates of Development Indicators, Location AI for National Security, the building of novel ML model execution optimizations, and simulations of accelerator designs are examples of the projects with great potential to advance knowledge and dependent on the faster network this new cyberinfrastructure expansion provides.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes report for CC*/DMZ grant 

As the size of datasets increases, the importance of fast, low-congestion network paths becomes critical to science since these datasets often must be transferred from one location to another.  William & Mary’s research computing network needed to be upgraded to allow for higher data-transfer speeds.  Specifically, this project accomplished the following: 

 - Improved network bandwidth between our Main campus in Williamsburg, VA and the Virginia Institute of Marine Science.   

- Created a 40Gbps Science DMZ research network with data-transfer and multiple perfSONAR nodes. 

- Equipped major end users with 10Gbps connectivity to the research network. 

- Equipped our data-transfer node with a Globus license for efficient data sharing. 

For the first phase of the project, the hardware (perfSONAR, data-transfer node, new and switching equipment) was acquired and new cabling/fiber was installed into a few of our main and VIMS campus buildings to accommodate 10Gbps networking.   During this time, we ran tests to determine our “baseline” network speeds which were a mixture of mostly 1Gbps links with some 10Gbps equipment.     

In the next phase, we upgraded our HPC centers on our main and VIMS campus to use Globus version 5 along with our new license.   We then learned how to create guest data collections through our data-transfer node.  We also upgraded all HPC fileservers to connect at 10Gbps.   

Once upgrades were completed, we commenced with another set of network tests to show that inter-campus file transfers could take advantage of the 40Gbps connection between campuses and that our data-transfer node can transfer files within our Science DMZ at near 10Gbps rates.   All tests show that this goal was achieved.  

During the second round of tests, much time was spent on understanding how to best use file-transfer software (scp, rclone, Globus, etc.) to transfer data as fast as possible between locations.  We now recommend Globus to all users for all file transfers. 

The final phase of this project was to educate our users with online documentation and a presentation on using Globus for file-transfers, including guest collections.  This documentation will be presented at all future HPC/RC training sessions. 

In the future, we plan to equip new users with 10Gbps connections when needed as well as continue to train users on leveraging the speeds through Globus.

Modified by: Eric J Walter
